natural problem: A boy has the following seven coins in his pocket: $2$ pennies, $2$ nickels, $2$ dimes, and $1$ quarter. He takes out two coins, records the sum of their values, and then puts them back with the other coins. He continues to take out two coins, record the sum of their values, and put them back. How many different sums can he record at most?
natural solution: The following pairs of numbers represent the values of the two coins the boy could take from his pocket: $$ \begin{array}{cccc} (1,1) & (1,5) & (1,10) & (1,25) \\ (5,5) & (5,10) & (5,25) & \\ (10,10) & (10,25) & & \\
\end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes coins :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "coins 1 = 2"
and h1 : "coins 5 = 2"
and h2 : "coins 10 = 2"
and h3 : "coins 25 = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> x y. x < 4 \<and> y < 4 \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> (coins (10 * x + y) = coins x + coins y)"
shows  "card {sums. \<exists> x y. x < 4 \<and> y < 4 \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> sums = coins (10 * x + y)} = 9"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A boy has the following seven coins in his pocket: $2$ pennies, $2$ nickels, $2$ dimes, and $1$ quarter. He takes out two coins, records the sum of their values, and then puts them back with the other coins. He continues to take out two coins, record the sum of their values, and put them back. How many different sums can he record at most? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 The following pairs of numbers represent the values of the two coins the boy could take from his pocket: $$ \begin{array}{cccc} (1,1) & (1,5) & (1,10) & (1,25) \\ (5,5) & (5,10) & (5,25) & \\ (10,10) & (10,25) & & \\
 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

theorem
fixes coins :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "coins 1 = 2"
and h1 : "coins 5 = 2"
and h2 : "coins 10 = 2"
and h3 : "coins 25 = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> x y. x < 4 \<and> y < 4 \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> (coins (10 * x + y) = coins x + coins y)"
shows  "card {sums. \<exists> x y. x < 4 \<and> y < 4 \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> sums = coins (10 * x + y)} = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: You have four types of coins: 1 cent, 5 cents, 10 cents, and 25 cents. You have 2 coins each of the first three types and 1 coin of the last type. If you add up the values of two different types of coins (with multiples less than 4), how many different sums can you get? The final answer is 9.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes coins :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "coins = [1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25]"
and h1 : "\<forall> c1 c2. c1 \<in> set coins \<and> c2 \<in> set coins \<and> c1 \<noteq> c2 \<longrightarrow> c1 + c2 \<in> set sums"
shows  "card (set sums) \<le> 9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A boy has the following seven coins in his pocket: $2$ pennies, $2$ nickels, $2$ dimes, and $1$ quarter. He takes out two coins, records the sum of their values, and then puts them back with the other coins. He continues to take out two coins, record the sum of their values, and put them back. How many different sums can he record at most? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 The following pairs of numbers represent the values of the two coins the boy could take from his pocket: $$ \begin{array}{cccc} (1,1) & (1,5) & (1,10) & (1,25) \\ (5,5) & (5,10) & (5,25) & \\ (10,10) & (10,25) & & \\
 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

theorem
fixes coins :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "coins = [1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25]"
and h1 : "\<forall> c1 c2. c1 \<in> set coins \<and> c2 \<in> set coins \<and> c1 \<noteq> c2 \<longrightarrow> c1 + c2 \<in> set sums"
shows  "card (set sums) \<le> 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: You have a set of coins consisting of two 1-cent coins, two 5-cent coins, two 10-cent coins, and one 25-cent coin. If you can make different sums using any two distinct coins, how many unique sums can you make? The answer is no more than 9.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: nat
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2"
and h2 : "dimes = 2"
and h3 : "quarters = 1"
and h4 : "pennies + nickels + dimes + quarters = 7"
and h5 : "\<forall> sum. \<exists> x y. (x \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> (y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> x ≠ y \<and> x + y = sum"
shows  "card {sum. \<exists> x y. (x \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> (y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> x ≠ y \<and> x + y = sum} = 9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A boy has the following seven coins in his pocket: $2$ pennies, $2$ nickels, $2$ dimes, and $1$ quarter. He takes out two coins, records the sum of their values, and then puts them back with the other coins. He continues to take out two coins, record the sum of their values, and put them back. How many different sums can he record at most? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 The following pairs of numbers represent the values of the two coins the boy could take from his pocket: $$ \begin{array}{cccc} (1,1) & (1,5) & (1,10) & (1,25) \\ (5,5) & (5,10) & (5,25) & \\ (10,10) & (10,25) & & \\
 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

theorem
fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: nat
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2"
and h2 : "dimes = 2"
and h3 : "quarters = 1"
and h4 : "pennies + nickels + dimes + quarters = 7"
and h5 : "\<forall> sum. \<exists> x y. (x \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> (y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> x ≠ y \<and> x + y = sum"
shows  "card {sum. \<exists> x y. (x \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> (y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}) \<and> x ≠ y \<and> x + y = sum} = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If you have 2 pennies, 2 nickels, 2 dimes, and 1 quarter, how many distinct sums can you make by choosing two different types of coins? The final answer is 9.

a_3.formal problem:

fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: nat
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2"
and h2 : "dimes = 2"
and h3 : "quarters = 1"
shows  "card {p + q |p q. p \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<and> q \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}} = 9"

theorem

a_3.informal problem: If you have 2 pennies, 2 nickels, 2 dimes, and 1 quarter, how many distinct sums can you make by adding two different coins together? The final answer is 9.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: nat
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2 * 5"
and h2 : "dimes = 2 * 10"
and h3 : "quarters = 1 * 25"
and h4 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<and> y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<longrightarrow> x \<noteq> y"
shows  "card (image (\<lambda>(x, y). x + y) (SIGMA x: {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}. {y. y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<and> x \<noteq> y})) = 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A boy has the following seven coins in his pocket: $2$ pennies, $2$ nickels, $2$ dimes, and $1$ quarter. He takes out two coins, records the sum of their values, and then puts them back with the other coins. He continues to take out two coins, record the sum of their values, and put them back. How many different sums can he record at most? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 The following pairs of numbers represent the values of the two coins the boy could take from his pocket: $$ \begin{array}{cccc} (1,1) & (1,5) & (1,10) & (1,25) \\ (5,5) & (5,10) & (5,25) & \\ (10,10) & (10,25) & & \\
 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

theorem
fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: nat
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2 * 5"
and h2 : "dimes = 2 * 10"
and h3 : "quarters = 1 * 25"
and h4 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<and> y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<longrightarrow> x \<noteq> y"
shows  "card (image (\<lambda>(x, y). x + y) (SIGMA x: {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters}. {y. y \<in> {pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters} \<and> x \<noteq> y})) = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If you have 2 pennies, 2 nickels, 2 dimes, and a quarter, and you cannot use two coins of the same type together, how many different sums can you make by adding the values of two different types of coins together? The final answer is 9.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes coinSum :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "coinSum = {x + y |x y. x \<in> {1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25} \<and> y \<in> {1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25}}"
shows  "card coinSum = 9"
a_6.formal solution:

 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

theorem
fixes coinSum :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "coinSum = {x + y |x y. x \<in> {1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25} \<and> y \<in> {1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25}}"
shows  "card coinSum = 9"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a set of coins with the following denominations: 1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25. If we create a new set by adding every pair of coins, how many unique sums can we get? The final answer is 9.

a_8.formal problem:
The problem is more of a combinatorial and counting problem rather than a theorem to be proven, and it doesn't translate directly into an Isabelle theorem. However, we can model the problem using sets and functions in Isabelle. We define a function that generates all possible sums and then count the number of distinct sums. Here is a potential Isabelle-like pseudocode:

```
fun coin_values :: "int list => int list"
where
"coin_values [] = []" |
"coin_values (x#xs) = map (\<lambda>y. x + y) xs @ coin_values xs"

definition possible_sums :: "int set"
where
"possible_sums = set (coin_values [1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, 25])"

value "card possible_sums"
```

This code first defines a function `coin_values` that takes a list of integers (representing the coin values) and generates all possible sums of two coins. The function `possible_sums` then converts this list into a set (removing duplicates) and `card possible_sums` computes the cardinality of this set (i.e., the number of distinct sums), which should be 9 as stated in the problem.

 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

However, we can model the problem using sets and functions in Isabelle. We define a function that generates all possible sums and then count the number of distinct sums. where

This code first defines a function `coin_values` that takes a list of integers (representing the coin values) and generates all possible sums of two coins. The function `possible_sums` then converts this list into a set (removing duplicates) and `card possible_sums` computes the cardinality of this set (i.e., the number of distinct sums), which should be 9 as stated in the problem.

a_8.informal problem: Given seven coins of values 1, 1, 5, 5, 10, 10, and 25 cents, find the number of distinct sums that can be made using any two coins. The final answer is 9.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: int
and sums :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2*5"
and h2 : "dimes = 2*10"
and h3 : "quarters = 1*25"
and h4 : "sums = {pennies + pennies, pennies + nickels, pennies + dimes, pennies + quarters, 
                   nickels + nickels, nickels + dimes, nickels + quarters, 
                   dimes + dimes, dimes + quarters}"
shows  "card sums = 9"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A boy has the following seven coins in his pocket: $2$ pennies, $2$ nickels, $2$ dimes, and $1$ quarter. He takes out two coins, records the sum of their values, and then puts them back with the other coins. He continues to take out two coins, record the sum of their values, and put them back. How many different sums can he record at most? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 The following pairs of numbers represent the values of the two coins the boy could take from his pocket: $$ \begin{array}{cccc} (1,1) & (1,5) & (1,10) & (1,25) \\ (5,5) & (5,10) & (5,25) & \\ (10,10) & (10,25) & & \\
 \end{array} $$Each of the above pairs has a sum that is different from the sum of each of the other pairs.
 Therefore there are $\boxed{9}$ different sums.
 *)

theorem
fixes pennies nickels dimes quarters :: int
and sums :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "pennies = 2"
and h1 : "nickels = 2*5"
and h2 : "dimes = 2*10"
and h3 : "quarters = 1*25"
and h4 : "sums = {pennies + pennies, pennies + nickels, pennies + dimes, pennies + quarters, 
                   nickels + nickels, nickels + dimes, nickels + quarters, 
                   dimes + dimes, dimes + quarters}"
shows  "card sums = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If you have 2 pennies, 2 nickels, 2 dimes, and a quarter, how many distinct sums can you make by adding together different pairs of these coins? The final answer is 9.
